dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want to take your anger to the grave, be my guest. But you can be fucking sure you'll take your son with you. He’s at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: (looking up) I’m sure. Hold. The moment of betrayal...but she doesn’t look sure a damned thing.

dialogues.text: MCILLHATTON steps into a phone box, dials. A voice answer

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Andersonstown Travel.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: Wolfe Tone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on.  22. MCILLHATTON glances over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY MCVEIGH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: I’ve got what we need. I’1ll take it to the man. The call is cut. EDDIE MCILLHATTON, a little put out, replaces the receiver. He steps out of the phone box, scopes the street. This is a lonely calling. EXT. BATTERSEA PARK - EARLY MORNING. COLLETTE and MAC stand by a shed.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: When you got away, you came here. It was too dangerous to call in because the whole city was crawling with cops. MAC takes her arm and leads her gently away. INT. GINGY’S HOUSE - SOUTH ARMAGH - DAY. GINGY kisses his wife and four kids goodbye and heads for the door. He looks hassled and annoyed. Through the windo we see the side of his newly painted van. GINGY HUGHES PLUMBING. Night or day, call 0845 666734.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: He hands her a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Memorise the number and the time and place of the first meeting, then burn it. Your code name is SHADOW DANCER. Don’t use the phone in the house unless you are sure there is no one else there. If anyone sees you in a phone box, say it’s a love affair you don’t want your mother to hear about. COLLETTE stares out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need this.  23. He hands over a piece of metal and plastic half the size a golf ball.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s an emergency bleep. Hide it well. If you press the button, half the world will come running. She takes it, but continues to gaze out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: My code name is Box Man. If you call in, you ask for--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I mean your real name.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: It’s better you don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: If you make a mistake, I’m dead -- right? I’d like to know your name. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: My name is Mac. She looks at him, like she’s seeing him for the first tim Who the hell is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l see you in Belfast. Make sure you’re at the rendezvous. INT. THE FRONT SEAT OF GINGY’S CAR - DAY GINGY HUGHES is spinning down the road to that pavilion again, but he’s not pleased about it. He parks ups and bristles as he marches inside. INT. THE PAVILION - SOUTH ARMAGH - CONTINUOUS. It’s dark in here, but nothing assuages GINGY’s anger.

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: What the hell’s the problem? I told you--  24. A torch-light flicks on. It illuminates the ghoulish face of KEVIN MULGREW, the IRA’s new head of Internal Security MULGREW. Mornin’, Gingy. You’se expecting someone else?

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: (stunned) No...no. GINGY turns to run, but it’s too late. MULGREW’S men have the place surrounded. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY KATE FLETCHER is on the phone. One of her junior officers interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Looks like Blue One is down. A moment of genuine shock on her face, but she recovers.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: His wife called the local priest. She was expecting him at the doctor's. The police have found his car. It was at one of the rendezvous points.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’1l deal with it. He leaves. She shuts the door, closes her eyes. A beat, whilst she gathers herself. She dials. Together again. Composed. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Give me the chief please. It’s Kate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GINGY HUGHES sits in a chair, naked, with a sack over his head. MULGREW. When, Gingy? MULGREW doesn’t receive an answer, so he yanks GINGY up a drags him to a filthy blood red bath.  25. He smashes his skull against it as GINGY screams in pain. MULGREW plunges his head into the water and holds him dow The rest of the crew watch. They don’t share MULGREW’s sadism. He yanks GINGY’s head up. We notice he is trying to avoid getting dirty water on a new pair of BRIGHT RED TRAINERS. MULGREW. (CONT’D) When did you start your touting?

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: (terrified) I’m a patriot. I’m just-- GINGY’s P.0.V. as his head goes under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE gazes out across the water. She is on her way ho at last. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - SITUATION ROOM - DAY FLETCHER on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I want everything you have out there. She listens.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. They have him. We're sure, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GINGY is back in the chair. MULGREW has put on a pair of leather gloves. MULGREW. Who reeled you in, Gingy?

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: No one. MULGREW strikes him hard. MULGREW. We have time, Gingy. More time than you’se could ever dream of.  26.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A TRAIN APPROACHING BELFAST STATION- DAY
dialogues.text: Smudged images of the city beyond a rain-soaked window. ~ the seat beside COLLETTE a newspaper headline shouts ‘PEA IN OUR TIME? LONDON AND DUBLIN HAIL ‘DOWNING STREET DECLARATION’ .’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A van guns down a dirt track in the driving rain. The doo opens and GINGY HUGHES is pulled out. MULGREW’S men drag him into a nearby field. MULGREW walks behind, trying not to get his trainers muddy. GINGY knows what’s coming. He’ a mumbling, gibbering wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE leaves the station. The rain stops. The sun shines. She’s close to home now and can’t contain herself She starts to run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GINGY is on his knees by a ditch. MULGREW holds a pistol his head.

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: (crying) Please...for my kids sake... MULGREW. You think we should forgive ye, Gingy?

dialogues.speaker: GINGY
dialogues.text: I beg you... MULGREW. Aye...maybe youse’re right. The quality of mercy should not be strained. What about that? MULGREW touches GINGY’s shoulder paternally, but we see from the faces of his crew that they don’t buy the possibility of a reprieve. CLOSE on the youngest. He looks like he’s about to shit h pants. MULGREW pulls the trigger. GINGY slumps forward, dead. MULGREW turns away. He looks irritably at his shoes to ma sure there is no blood on them.  27. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - DAY Motion again -- COLLETTE pounding the pavement. She round the corner, runs past a group of kids playing football in the street and struggles with her key in the lock. She bursts into... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - CONTINUOUS. The house is quiet. COLLETTE’S MOTHER is hunched over the stove. As she turns, the suffering of the years of war is etched indelibly into her face. MA conducts herself with unbearable dignity. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: He’s out back.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is he...

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: He’s fine. COLLETTE’S P.O.V. as she rushes through to... EXT. BACK YARD - CONTINUOUS. ...-where MARK is kicking a ball against the fence. He se her, stares a moment -- then runs.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Mark! COLLETTE sprints after him into... EXT. ALLEY - CONTINUOUS. Halfway down, she catches up.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Go away! She wrestles with him. He gives in, sobs, clings to her. Tight. Like he’s never going to let go. She presses his head to her neck. She’s home. It’s okay. Everything's all right now. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY FLETCHER’S on the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Where? Are you sure it’s him?  28. She listens.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, I‘’1l deal with the family. They're our responsibility. Replaces the phone slowly. There’s absolutely no emotion there now. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - KITCHEN - EVENING An ordinary family scene. MARK is finishing his tea, whil COLLETTE and her MOTHER wash up. The door opens and in wa COLLETTE’S two brothers, GERRY and PADDY. GERRY is taller and older. He is brooding and handsome, with cropped hair naturally a leader. But PADDY got all the emotional intelligence. He is shorter and bulkier with long, unkemp hair and a moustache. There’s a warmth here. They’re a family, right or wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: We heard a rumour our girl was back. He hugs his sister and whispers;

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was all over the news. Ma’s been in pieces. He kisses his mother. GERRY takes a hunk of bread off the side and wipes some of the left-over gravy from MARK’s plate. He winks at his sister.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (with his mouth full) You all right, Collette? She nods. GERRY switches on the TV. The British and Irish Prime Ministers are giving a press conference

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You heard about this?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We’re busting their balls and they want us to settle for a piece of fucking paper. MA. Mind your language in front of Mark please, Gerard.  29. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MA., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And who’s to say it isn’t something. He turns back to the TV and whacks up the volume. The British Prime Minister, John Major, is answering a question. MAJOR. Of course the document entertains the possibility of a united Ireland. But it also very clearly recognises the right of the people of Northern Ireland to determine their own future. Any process must be based on the consent of both communities. We cut back to the newscaster. He intones gravely;

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: But even as the two Prime Ministers made that announcement, police in Northern Ireland discovered a hooded body on the border. Now we're looking at shots of GINGY’s house. Kids toys li abandoned in the garden. NEWSCASTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) The dead man has been named as Mr Gerard ‘Gingy’ Hughes. His family deny claims that he was a security force informer. ANGLE on GERRY. ON PADDY. ON COLLETTE. BACK ON the TV as the segment ends with shots of kids bik in a garden. EXT. COLLETTE’S BACK YARD - A FEW MINUTES LATER. PADDY is playing football with MARK. He collapses and the boy tumbles all over him. COLLETTE watches, smiling. GERRY joins her on the step. He takes in the scene. Maybe who knows -- he’s a little envious. That isn’t his style.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Glad you made it.  30. She nods, still watching her son.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were they waiting? She hesitates, like she’s working out what’s best to say.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah. GERRY gets up again and, for a moment, we think he’1l pla a hand upon her shoulder, but it’s beyond him. He disappears into the house. PADDY joins her. MARK jumps onto his lap again.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Aaagh! You little bugger. Go shoot at goal. Man U one nil down with a minute to go. Penalty!!! MARK trudges off happily. PADDY turns to his sister.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s okay. She watches her son strike the football and then jump ont the swing. They both know it’s more complicated than that

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quieter) How ‘bout you?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m fine. He ruffles her hair.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: They said on the news the girl ran down a tube tunnel. PADDY looks at her. These are crazy risks we run.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you reckon on this document?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Gerry says our leaders want a ticket to fancy handshakes at the White House.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you think? A beat.  31.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: We made a promise. That’s what Gerry says. So there it is. GERRY is the self-appointed keeper of the flame. And they’re all still trapped by that day. Except that COLLETTE isn’t any more. Or maybe she is. ON HER FACE as she works the angles. Relief. Guilt. Hope. Fear. She's got no bloody idea where she stands. He leans closer.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) This’ll cheer you up. You know the peeler who tried to put us away for the guy at the print- works? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This Friday... He clicks his fingers. This is a different PADDY. He’s go from fatigued warrior to bigot in a heartbeat. And although she loves him to bits, he suddenly doesn’t know her at all. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - IN HER BEDROOM - NIGHT COLLETTE takes the panic button out of her handbag. She looks around for somewhere to hide it, opts for her underwear drawer. She pushes it right to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Chinook thuds in. MAC tips out the back and walks to th perimeter wire, where a car is waiting. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - DAY MAC walks past the glass wall to the situation room and into the main office. Maybe a dozen people in front of screens. It’s quiet, business-like. Just another office. dumps a rucksack on his desk.  32. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY MAC enters, closes the door. They look at each other. May some personal history here, or the prospect of it being made.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Your idea.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: But your catch.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I heard we lost one. He means you lost him.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened? She doesn’t want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We picked up a phone call from London to that travel shop on the Andersonstown Road. Gerry McVeigh’s girl.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Nothing we could make sense of. But if he’s planning something, Northern Command doesn’t know about it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: He’s going freelance?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe. So we need your girl up to speed - and fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac drives in, gets out, locks his car and heads for the house in the corner of the yard.  33. INT. MAC’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS. The phone is ringing. He picks it up. It’s his daughter, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I know. I’m sorry. I meant to call before I left London.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mum says you might not be coming this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I told her I--

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Something new. I’ve just--

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I can’t talk about it, love. You know that. It’ll take a few months, then--

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Will you be here for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’ll try. He’s not convincing. And its complicated.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (quieter) Will you see Mum when you come?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I don’t know. Not the answer she wanted.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for the cheque. I’1ll get it tomorrow. Mum’s promised to take me after school. Another phone is ringing. The secure line.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. Don’t go away. He puts the receiver down on the desk and goes to pick up the other line.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir, it’s all set for tomorrow. Mrs Fletcher has assigned three surveillance teams. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I checked with TCG. They’ve no wind of anything. In fact, nothing at all tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Good. He puts down the phone, returns to his daughter. But she’s gone. He looks at the receiver and puts it slowly back onto the cradle. This is his life. Married to some fucking agent who would have killed him until yesterday. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - IN HER BEDROOM - A FEW HOURS LATER We hear a cry in the dark. COLLETTE wakes with a jolt to find MARK beside her.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Mark, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: My bed is wet.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh...okay. COLLETTE gets up, dressed only in a T-shirt. She feels hi pajamas in the dark. The bottoms are soaking. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Take these off. She wraps him in a towel and lays his sleepy head down on her pillow. She goes through to...  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...-where she strips his bed, before returning to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+.-where her mother is waiting. MA. He’s okay?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: He hasn’t done this for months. Ma doesn’t budge. Her message is clear enough.

dialogues.speaker: MA., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Neither of us slept while you were gone.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Ma, please...you wouldn’t do this to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: If you won’t tell Gerry that you've had enough, I will. COLLETTE squeezes past.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Goodnight Ma. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS COLLETTE gets back into bed and puts an arm around her so She stares up at the ceiling. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LAUNDRY ROOM - DAY COLLETTE is in the tiny utility room behind the kitchen, bent over the washing machine, which isn’t working. She puzzles over what’s wrong, punches a few buttons and finally gives the door a good KICK. It starts to work again. As she smiles to herself, it springs an alarming leak.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Shit...Mam!  36. MA comes in and now the two women fiddle with the dials. Eventually, MA switches it off at the wall and pushes the door shut hard enough to stem the leak. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (kicking it again) Paddy couldn’t fix his own bloody hair! Both women laugh. MA leans closer and kisses COLLETTE’s forehead. A moment of unalloyed warmth. But it doesn’t fi the yawning chasm between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE is taking MARK to school, an arm around his shoulder. She’s stopped to chat to a friend. Just small talk. He's out of control, so he is. Someone should tell her. But the friend seems kind of in a hurry to move on, like she doesn’t want them to be seen together in public. CLOSE on COLLETTE for a beat as she reads this. Not the first time by any means, but a tiny wound all the same. They break up. COLLETTE and MARK walk away past an army patrol. A soldier suddenly blocks her way. He’s an older guy with a rugged face, but he’s friendly. Or at least polite.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (points) We need to check your bag, Ma’am. She lets him search it. No point in a confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your pockets.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Sargeant, I’m just taking my son to school. But he’s not budging. She spreads her arms.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd be kind enough to step into the doorway here. COLLETTE frowns. But the guy is still being extremely polite, so she complies.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you could put your arms against the wall. She shakes her head, but does so. The long RAINCOAT she i wearing is spread wide, like a bat’s wings. Or a screen.  The soldier checks her raincoat pockets. He begins with her right wrist. The search is tight. slow. Too slow.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m just taking my son to school, Sargeant. No answer. Elbows. Shoulders. Arm-pits. Waist. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Is this necessary? Ribs. Slower still. Breasts. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Jesus! 37. It is As she tries to break away, he takes hold of her hair wit his left-hand and grips tight.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Stay there...or you’re in Castlereagh for the night and we'll stick your boy over the other side of the wall. He puts a hand down her blouse, in her bra, cups her nipple. TIGHT on COLLETTE’s face as she turns away, bites her lip CLOSE on MARK. He knows something is wrong. The soldier slips his hand out. Back to her waist. Slower still. Hips. Thigh. Knee.  38. Inner thigh. The band of her knickers.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since your brothers blew his legs off... Into her knickers. TIGHT on COLLETTE’s face to see a tear roll down her chee

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All my friend Joe has to pleasure his wife... Lower.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is the fingers of his right hand... She breaks away, staggers. She leans against the wall, sobs. The soldiers move off. TIGHT on MARK again as he watches her. INT. MAC’S CAR - ON LINENHALL STREET - DAY MAC speaks into a hand-held radio. A DRIVER is beside him

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (tense) You got her? EXT. NEARBY STREET - CONTINUOUS. A man selling newspapers leans into a hidden microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Negative. INT. MAC’S CAR - CONTINUOUS. He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (mutters ) C'mon... Checks again. Watches the empty street.  39. No sign of her. Time crawls by. Where the fuck is she?

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into the radio) She’s not coming. Let’s get outta’ here! The car guns away. And he’s furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up COLLETTE as she approaches her son’s school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re CLOSE on MARK as he waits for his mum in the classroom and catch his DELIGHT as she arrives. Watching this reunion, the HEADTEACHER approaches. She has a kindl manner.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER
dialogues.text: Miss. McVeigh, I’m sorry to trouble you. Could you spare a few minutes? It’s obvious she means without MARK.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (touching his shoulder) I won’t be long. The head takes her down to an office. She produces a child’s picture. It depicts a man with a gun lying ina pool of blood.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER
dialogues.text: I thought you should see this. It’s not the first. COLLETTE stares at the painting. She doesn’t look like sh really wants to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know that Mark’s father was killed just before he came to us, Miss. McVeigh, but I worry that-

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Mark's father was murdered Mrs. Davies.  40.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Yes. I understand he was a Volunteer-

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He was a patriot.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER
dialogues.text: Miss. McVeigh, I don’t seek to make a judgement. I just want to draw your attention to the fact that your son is struggling to concentrate on his school work.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (chastened) I understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEADTEACHER
dialogues.text: Your mother said that Mark had been upset by your recent absence, so perhaps that explains it. The HEAD is making a point here. COLLETTE folds up the painting.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (frosty now) Thank you, Mrs. Davies. I appreciate your concern. EXT. FALLS ROAD - A FEW MINUTES LATER. COLLETTE walks home with MARK in the gathering darkness. She drapes an arm around him. He thinks

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: How was school?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: How were your lessons?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What was the best bit of the day? about it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: When you came to pick me up.  4l. COLLETTE pulls him tighter. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - A FEW MINUTES LATER. COLLETTE comes through the door and throws her keys in th pot. MARK runs out towards the yard. COLLETTE’s mother is cooking the kids dinner, but she’s tense. MA. You have a visitor. COLLETTE frowns at her mother’s demeanor and tone. She walks through to... EXT. COLLETTE’S BACK YARD - CONTINUOUS. ...-where a man is sitting with his back to her. He alrea has an arm around her son. He turns. It is KEVIN MULGREW. MULGREW. Collette; what about you’se?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Hello, Kevin. MULGREW. This is a beautiful wee fella’ you've got here. MARK doesn’t look too sure. COLLETTE scoops him up. MULGR stands.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I have to give him tea. MULGREW. We need to talk about London.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Later. MULGREW. A Volunteer is never off duty, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Nor is a mother. For a moment, he looks like he’1ll insist. But then he smiles. MULGREW. (nodding) Sure. Tomorrow, then. We have time, so we do.  42. He waits, makes her sweat. PADDY arrives through the back gate. We sense immediately that he cannot abide this man.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (to Collette) What the fuck’s he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s just leaving. MULGREW. Doing my job, Volunteer McVeigh.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Then fuck off and do it somewhere else. MULGREW. (to Collette, unruffled) Look after yourself, Collette. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: To talk about London. PADDY frowns as he watches him disappear down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDDIE MCILLHATTON approaches a second-hand book-shop... INT. BOOK-SHOP - CAMDEN - CONTINUOUS. A frumpy middle-aged woman in reception nods at him, but ignores her and plunges down the back stairs to a small basement. Standard lamps, photographs, the smell of glue...a forger paradise. On a stool, MAX CAMPBELL; chain-smoking, fiftie half-German, half-Irish. He looks over his half-rimmed glasses.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You Gerry’s man?

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: I was told no names.  43. CAMPBELL rolls his eyes. Kids. MCILLHATTON tips the stole pass onto the table, along with photographs of GERRY and COLLETTE. CAMPBELL looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Good lookin’ bird. Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: You don’t need to know.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Two days. And make sure you have the cash. You can remind our Gerry I’m not a bloody charity. INT. COLLETTE’s HOME - EARLY MORNING. COLLETTE lies awake. MARK is snuggled up beside her, fast asleep. All is quiet. There’s a distant rumble, then...

dialogues.speaker: CRASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - A SPLIT SECOND LATER The dawn calm is broken as a convoy of armored Land Rover tears around the corner. Armed officers tip out. MAC is behind them. He hangs back as the uniforms sledgehammer COLLETTE’s front door. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - CONTINUOUS. The UNIFORMS’ P.O.V. as they charge upstairs. Screams and shouts from neighbors outside. A helicopter overhead. COLLETTE is on the landing, dressed only in a T-shirt and knickers.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (shaken, angry) What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED OFFICER
dialogues.text: Get dressed, Miss McVeigh. You're under arrest on suspicion of attempted murder. You have the right to remain silent, but anything you do say may be taken down and later used as evidence against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MARK’s FACE as he emerges from the bedroom. He looks like he’s about to wet himself again. COLLETTE ushers him gently back towards the bedroom. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS. She tries to close the door behind her, but the officer puts his boot in the gap.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: For God's sake! He doesn’t budge. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - DOWNSTAIRS - CONTINUOUS. More officers piling in and fanning out to search the ground floor. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LANDING - CONTINUOUS. MA Steps out of her room. A face of cold fury.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED OFFICER
dialogues.text: Don’t get involved, ma’am. You’1l need to look after the boy. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS MARK in her arms. He’s crying.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s all right, love. I'll be back before you know it. But of course it’s not bloody all right. She’s got no ide what her status is now and that fear is written all over her face. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - DOWNSTAIRS - CONTINUOUS. Chaos. Quick cuts as: Two officers pull a drawer from a desk. Another sweeps his hand along a kitchen cabinet, tipping everything onto the floor. A fourth rips the back away from a television. She's getting the full treatment.  45. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LANDING - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE steps out of the bedroom. She’s behind the offic and trying gently to detach MARK from her leg. MA bars th way. MA. Leave her.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED OFFICER
dialogues.text: Get out of the way, Mrs. McVeigh. MA. We've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED OFFICER
dialogues.text: We've all had enough. MA. She’s a mother for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED OFFICER
dialogues.text: And I’m a father. But that won’t stop you cutting me down. They stare at each other a moment with worldy, weary eyes And then he roughly thrusts her aside. COLLETTE frees herself from MARK and he begins to cry. He tries to follo her.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Mammy ! MA scoops him up. He’s screaming now. On COLLETTE’S FACE as she is forced down the stairs. On the UNIFORMED OFFICER’S grim expression as he brings u the rear.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - CONTINUOUS. ANGLE on COLLETTE as she passes MAC en route to the back the Land Rover. If looks could kill...

dialogues.speaker: CRASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - SECONDS LATER. MARK still trying to run after his mother. He’s hysterica MA tries to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE is dragged down a corridor. Detainees’ clothes (concealed by a cloth sack) hang on a peg outside each door. We hear;

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m Richard McIlwaine, Republican. If you’re Republican, tell ‘em nothing! COLLETTE breaks free and hammers the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Richard, it’s Collette!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hang in there, Collette. Tell ‘em nothing! COLLETTE is roughly man-handled down the corridor and int a cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE is seated. MAC steps in, closes the door behind him and drops her file on the desk. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Where were you? No answer. MAC thumps the table so hard she jumps.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I was looking after my son! I...I couldn’t get away! He leans towards her, hands on the desk. COLLETTE (CONT’D) It’s what happened!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I save you from a lifetime ina stinking prison cell. And you’re going to sit here and tell me you didn’t turn up because you couldn't find a fucking nanny! She's shocked. His anger is un-nerving. He sits.  47.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have one minute to give me something or you’re down that corridor looking at a charge sheet. A beat. She nods. She gets it; she’s really screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Have you seen your brothers?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What does Gerry think of the ‘Declaration.’

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What’s he going to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I...I don’t know. Really, I--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: He was round at your house yesterday afternoon, just after the document was signed. It was all over the TV news. What did he say? She stares at the table top.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You said they wouldn’t be hurt...you promised that. Brushes her hand nervously across it now.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t want ‘of course.’ He’s not going through that hoop again. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (hesitatant) There’s something tomorrow.  48. Go on. She won't.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Paddy’s going to kill the guy...the detective who tried to put us both away for the murder of my boss at the print works. Henderson. He’s a big shot now. CID.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He didn’t say. That’s all I can tell you. INT. A CAR IN A CITY CENTRE CAR PARK - NIGHT. MAC is in the back with COLLETTE. A different DRIVER is a the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Let’s go over it again.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I've got it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (steely) Again. COLLETTE gazes out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I was questioned by a detective and by a man from London who called himself Mr...Jenkins. I thought...I assumed he was MI5.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What did he ask you?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He wanted to know why I had been away from Belfast last week. Where was I? What was I doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Did he know you were in England?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Suspected...constant questions. Wasn’t I here? Didn’t I do this? But no evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (sighs) Mulgrew’s a cunning piece of shit. He may not come at you right away. So be ready. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s time to go. She continues to gaze out at the black night. She doesn’t want to go. She shivers. He reaches out and closes his hand around her's. A moment. Something here. She does not meet his gaze. COLLETTE steps out and walks rapidly away into the darkness. She does not look back.

dialogues.speaker: TASKING CO-ORDINATING GROUP
dialogues.text: Through an internal window, we can see a group of men around a table. There are maps of Belfast on all the wall A police chief sits at the head, next to KATE FLETCHER. S looks like she’s arguing the toss about something as... We spin to see MAC striding down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: MAC bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Tell me this is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Close the door and sit down.  50.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’ve just got a call to--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (sternly) Sit down. MAC shuts the door, but remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You want the SAS hiding out in his garden?

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR STAFF OFFICER 1
dialogues.text: Derek Henderson is one of our own. We can’t just sit here and--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (looks at FLETCHER) Tell him. FLETCHER shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you do that, our player is finished. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Mac, you know what Paddy McVeigh is like. We have a chance here to take his entire team out of circulation. We must take it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You lay an ambush and there’1ll be the mother and father of all witch-hunts. We might as well publish the name in the fucking Belfast Telegraph.

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR STAFF OFFICER 1
dialogues.text: That’s not true. We can--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’m gonna’ call London. FLETCHER glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want everything on hold until I’ve talked to Buchanan. He turns away.  51.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’ve already talked to him, Mac. MAC stares in disbelief. He’s angry at them, at himself. He’s been out-manoeuvered here and he’s not sure how and why.

dialogues.speaker: LATER.
dialogues.text: MAC by the coffee machine. FLETCHER joins him.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You're too old to be making a fool of yourself like that. MAC waits as the last of the coffee is spat out. He takes slug.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Eight months work. And you're going to blow it in a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: That’s not true and you know it. We'll make sure Paddy survives. There’1ll be plenty of suspects.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll be sure to tell her that. Or maybe you can give her boy a cuddle at the funeral. FLETCHER walks away. She’s pissed off now.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy playing God, Kate? She swings around.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: No, Mac. I don’t. Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to know why I’m sitting in that glass office? I’m not smarter than you. I’m not tougher than you. We all know I’m nowhere near as experienced as you. He’s not going to offer an answer.  52.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sitting there because I’m prepared to make these decisions and you’re not. Somebody has to. So perhaps you'd like to stop beating me up about it. She stalks off. MAC dumps the cup in the trash bin. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM — MORNING CLOSE on COLLETTE’s face as she sleeps. A hand is placed over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Sshh...it’s me.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Christ...Paddy. What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: We need you. Kieran Doherty was picked up last night.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: But... She works through the implications... COLLETTE (CONT’D) I can’t...I need to look after--

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: He'll be fine with Ma.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Why do you need me?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Get dressed, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Paddy, I can’t. I--

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Is something wrong?  53.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No...no.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Then get dressed. This is a PADDY we don’t know; the man a war made ugly. EXT. COLLETTE’S HOME - A FEW MINUTES LATER. COLLETTE walks out of her front door and gets into a beat up car. A young thug is behind the wheel. Paddy sits besi him. They are both wearing leather gloves. We switch to.. INT. CAR - CONTINUOUS. «+. and COLLETTE’S P.O.V. as they wind through the desola dawn streets.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (turning around) Henderson pulls out of a cul-de- sac off the Newtownards Road at 7.30 on the nail. He drives a silver Granada. You block. We do the rest from the van. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got that?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The driver pulls up and two more thugs emerge from the shadows of a tower block. One is wearing a BASEBALL CAP. He’s an unattractive, spotty youth. Both squeeze in beside COLLETTE. They look like they migh be high. INT. SAFE HOUSE - A FEW MINUTES LATER. THROUGH THE WINDOW as the car pulls up and they pile into the house. Three AK-Ms lie on the kitchen table, their butts removed to make them easy to conceal. There’s also heap of balaclavas. PADDY checks his watch. They wait. CLOSE on each face in turn. Nobody meets anyon else’s eye. COLLETTE excuses herself. She climbs the stairs, finds a toilet, sits on it.  54. Shuts her eyes. Shitting, fucking hell. Gets up again, crosses the hall. There is a phone beside the bed. She glances over her shoulder. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (whispers) I need to speak to the Box Man.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One moment please. Checks over her shoulder again.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Now! Footsteps on the stairs... INT. STAIRS - CONTINUOUS. The spotty thug is on the bottom step. He’s looking for her.

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL CAP
dialogues.text: Anyone there? INT. BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS. A voice on the line.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is Box Man.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s Shadow Dancer.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m in...I’m in. Don’t shoot. There is a knock. The THUG opens the door. He looks suspicious. She puts down the receiver. He heard. He must have heard...  55.

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL CAP
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (flustered) Sure. Fine... A beat. He’s going to denounce her...

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL CAP
dialogues.text: He says we’ve gotta’ go. INT. COLLETTE’S CAR - A FEW MINUTES LATER. COLLETTE drives. Next to her sits BASEBALL CAP. They have been teamed up together. He’s nervous, fidgety. They follow PADDY and the other men, who are in a beaten VAN.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: We SWOOP across the city as the convoy winds through the streets. The first commuters are making their way into town. INT. COLLETTE’S CAR - FIFTEEN MINUTES LATER. They have parked CLOSE TO TARGET. COLLETTE checks her watch. ANGLE on the DASHBOARD CLOCK. 7.25. COLLETTE drives into Newtonards Road. The van speeds past and swings around, so that they face each other either si of a cul-de-sac. 7.27. BASEBALL CAP looks like he’s going to shit his pant INT. HENDERSON’S HOUSE ON THE NEWTONARDS ROAD - DAY. HENDERSON is at his breakfast table, with his wife and tw kids. They eat in silence. The man they want to kill. Just an ordinary kind of guy... INT. COLETTE’S CAR - DAY. COLLETTE puts on her balaclava. BASEBALL CAP does the sam  56. 7.29. A beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land Rovers tear out of the cul-de-sac, a megaphone blasting;

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You are surrounded. Put down your weapons. INT. COLETTE’S CAR - CONTINUOUS They’re frozen. BASEBALL CAP tips out of the car...

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No! Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He RUNS. Blam, blam, blam! He’s down. Groaning... ON PADDY through the window of the van -- he’s shouting - ON COLLETTE as bullets thump into the rear of her car. PADDY’s moving. The van’s roaring CLOSER. A door’s flung open.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Run! No way.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now! Christ. Go. She jumps out -- dives in. PADDY slams his foot down.  57. INT. VAN - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE’S P.O.V. as they speed towards a junction. Too fast. They smash into parked cars. Paddy’s fighting to ke control -- slewing -- sliding -- scraping... EXT. STREET - CONTINUOUS. Accelerating again -- pedestrians running -- Land Rovers pouring down narrow side streets -- a police helicopter SWOOPING LOW. INT. HELICOPTER - CONTINUOUS. Shot of the pilot’s monitor.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: (into microphone) North on Holywood. INT. MAC’S CAR - A NEARBY STREET - CONTINUOUS. MAC is half out, speaking into a radio.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Back off! Waits. They’re not taking a blind bit of notice.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit. He gets into the car. The DRIVER accelerates away. EXT. STREET - CONTINUOUS. The VAN pegs it through a red light. PADDY hits a car sid on. He veers onto a pavement and shoppers run screaming. INT. VAN - CONTINUOUS. He swings back onto the road -- brakes -- hits another ca - spins -- rights himself -- accelerates until... A cop Land Rover pulls out of a street in front and the v SLAMS RIGHT INTO IT... Twists... Turns over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slides (on its side)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE’S HORIZONTAL P.O.V as the van hits a tree and comes to a shattering halt. Somebody’s groaning in the back.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Get out! EXT. STREET - CONTINUOUS. They stagger into the street. PADDY crouches down and fires off a burst of ammunition towards the pursuing Land Rovers.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Split up! ON COLLETTE as she runs, breathing ragged. She turns left, right. A quiet residential street. Into t drive of a house, opening a gate... EXT. GARDEN - CONTINUOUS. Across a lawn, over the fence to... EXT. ALLEY - CONTINUOUS. ...-where she rips off her balaclava and drops it ina hedge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking slowly. Limping. She’s trying to collect herself. She breathes in deep. The sun is shining. She smiles for an old lady walking he dog. EXT. COLLETTE’S GARDEN - AN HOUR LATER COLLETTE unlocks the back door.  59. INT. COLLETTE’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS. Inside, all is quiet. She leans against the wall, next to the sideboard with photographs of her kid brother Sean, o Gerry and Paddy, of her Mum and Dad, of Mark with his father... She breaks down... Shaking like a leaf... .-+-until she drags herself back together. She wipes her eyes, walks slowly through to... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS .+.-where her MOTHER is sitting silently at the table. COLLETTE puts on the kettle. MA. I told him you’d gone to see a friend. COLLETTE takes down two cups and puts a tea bag in each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC at his desk, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATIONS OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No sir. Nobody in or out of the house except the mother and the boy. Paddy’s gone to ground up in the Ardoyne.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Mulgrew?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATIONS OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No sir. Not yet. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - EVENING COLLETTE and MARK are reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Cc -A- T. Now let me cover it and you can try.  60.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) c-A-T

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Great. (she closes the book). Once more; how do you spell bat?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Mat?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Car?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: c-A (thinks about it) R. She hugs him. COLLETTE stands and ruffles his hair. She puts her head around the door of the kitchen, where MA is cooking their tea.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Mam, I’1l be two minutes. MA. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I said I'd get Mark some beans for his dinner. MA. I have beans. COLLETTE looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I‘1l just be a second. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - SECONDS LATER. We follow COLLETTE to a NEWSAGENT on the corner...  61. INT. NEWSAGENT - CONTINUOUS. ...where she has come for a copy of the BELFAST TELEGRAPH AMBUSHED! yells the headline. COLLETTE reads the story as she walks towards the counter.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSAGENT
dialogues.text: Looks like he’s going to be okay. She glances up. She has no idea what he’s talking about. NEWSAGENT (CONT’D) The kid the bastards shot. Declan Walshe; he’s old Marian’s son from number seventy-nine. She’s had a rotten life, hasn’t she, what with--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s dead. She points to the article. ANGLE on the headline: One dea as IRA unit is ‘caught in the act.’

dialogues.speaker: NEWSAGENT
dialogues.text: (smiles) My sister’s a nurse up at the RVH. Word is he’s going to pull through. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE striding towards a phone box. She shoves the newspaper in the bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE dials, hears...

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How can I help?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s Shadow Dancer. I need to speak to Box Man.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One moment please. She waits impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Shadow Dancer.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s alive.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: The boy! The one in the baseball cap! The one you shot!

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s in the hospital. He’s--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He saw me! When we were in the house...when I made that call. He heard.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes! If I wasn’t Paddy’s sister, he’d have blabbed right there.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll deal with it. COLLETTE cuts the connection. She straightens again, glances nervously over her shoulder. EXT. STREET - SECONDS LATER. She leaves the telephone box and gets only four or five paces before she notices KEVIN MULGREW leaning against a wall. He’s been watching her. MULGREW. What about you’se Collette?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Kevin. MULGREW. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I just have to--. MULGREW. Now. He gestures towards a nearby car. INT. CAR - A FEW MINUTES LATER. MULGREW is driving.  63. MULGREW. You got a problem with your phone, Collette?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No. MULGREW. You usually take a walk into the night?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (trying hard to smile) I live with my mother, Kevin. I don’t want her to hear everything I've got to say. He smiles back, but there’s no mirth in his eyes. IRA. SAFE HOUSE - MINUTES LATER. MULGREW and COLLETTE sit either side of a formica table. kettle is boiling. The place is a dump. MULGREW. You want coffee?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No thanks. He stands, makes one for himself. He’s in no hurry. He sips his drink, lights a cigarette. MULGREW. Paddy’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Thank God. MULGREW waits. Sits down, leans forward. MULGREW. When did you first hear about the operation, Collette? A beat. Is it a trap?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: This morning. In the car.  MULGREW. In the car, this mornin’?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah. MULGREW. You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. MULGREW. No one mentioned it before then?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No. MULGREW. Paddy drop you a few hints...

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No. MULGREW. ...tip you off they were going to take out the guy who tried to put you away? She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No. MULGREW. What if I told you that’s not the way he remembers it? She holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Then I'd say you're lying. My brother wouldn’t give you the time of day. 64. MULGREW stubs out his cigarette, gets up slowly, empties the ash tray, washes it and returns to his seat. MULGREW. (with cold, hard eyes) See, Collette, it’s like this; only two men knew the time and place. So is it big Gerry who’s been squealing to the Brits? Is it his shaggy-haired brother? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or did one of them blab his fat mouth off to the sister every volunteer in Belfast wants to nail to the bed?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (blushing) I don’t know what you’re talking about. MULGREW. We lose you in London, but then you come home like nothin’ ever happened. The peelers break down your Ma’s door and haul you into Castlereagh. But you’re out again by teatime, like nothin’ ever happened.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: They knew I’d been away. MULGREW. Who?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: There was an Englishman and-- MULGREW. What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Jenkins. MULGREW.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I guess...yeah. MULGREW. What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Where was I? What had I been doing? MULGREW. What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: That I'd been staying with an aunt in the south. MULGREW. Without your son?  66.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I told him it was a love affair that was none of his business. MULGREW. They have any evidence you were over the water...pictures...surveillance.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No MULGREW. Which one asked about London?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (frowns ) Mac. It’s a trick he’s used before. MULGREW. Who's Mac?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (trying hard to retain her composure) The one...the English guy. MULGREW. You said his name was Jenkins. She hesitates. Trying to keep the panic from her face now

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Mac Jenkins. MULGREW. You’se were friendly then? First name terms an’ all? He stands. MULGREW. (CONT’D) Youse’re red-lighted, McVeigh. Don’t leave Belfast for any reason.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE...
dialogues.text: RUNNING down a rain-lashed street. Panic in her eyes...  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uniform cops pouring off a ward. MAC holds up some ID.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’m looking for the kid.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Too late. He’s making his excuses to our Lord. As far as the cop is concerned, a piece of IRA scum who g what he deserved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE arrives on the pavement opposite, soaked, just a MAC emerges from the hospital entrance. No one else is about and they eyeball each other a moment He nods and draws a finger across his throat. COLLETTE shakes her head. He hasn’t...he could not have.. INT. MAC’S CAR - A MINUTE LATER. A red traffic light through the rain-soaked windscreen. About to pull off when the door opens and COLLETTE jumps into the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Jesus! He pushes her head roughly down, so she is out of view, a accelerates away. He takes a roundabout at sixty. Roars up the hill out of town. As soon as he turns off the main road, onto a dirt track, she PUNCHES him. Smack into the face. Hard. He raises an arm for protection, slams on the brakes, ski to a halt. She’s going at him now, punching, scratching...

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For God's sake! He takes hold of both her arms.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I trusted you! She tries to break free, but he won’t release her.  68. COLLETTE (CONT’D) I gave you what you asked for. You said no one would be hurt! He lets go. COLLETTE (CONT’D) I have to get out of here. He’s stony faced. That’s not an option. COLLETTE (CONT’D) We need to go home and pick up my my son.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Calm down, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you mean calm down? Mulgrew knows. He’s red-lighted me!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He tricked me. I got mixed up. I said I’d been interrogated by a man called Jenkins, but then I used your name.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Mac?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. I told him it was a Christian name, but he knew.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (watching rivulets of rain run down the windscreen) It’s his job to make you think he knows.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Then he’s doing it damned bloody--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (tougher ) Calm down, Collette. She covers her eyes, groans.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t take you out. Not yet.  69. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (desolate) I said that you’d use me and then...(clicks her fingers). You promised me that wasn’t true.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: And it isn’t. You made a small mistake. You'll say that I introduced myself as Mr Jenkins, but I was with a colleague who referred to me consistently as Mac. She thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember who you are. Remember where you’ve come from and what you've done. One mistake doesn’t make you a tout.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Did you kill him? She gestures over her shoulder to indicate she means Baseball Cap back in the hospital. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Did you go in there and kill him?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You were going to? A beat. Of course not, but no harm in having her think he might have done.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’m here for you. Day and night. Waiting. Watching. If I think you're at risk, we'll take you out. A long silence. CLOSE ON COLLETTE. Doubt. Fear. But a yearning to trust him. To anchor herself. She didn’t know how much she wanted to begin again. She nods. She accepts. She’s his girl now.  70.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m sorry. EXT. BELFAST STREET - A FEW MINUTES LATER. MAC'S car pulls up on a deserted street. COLLETTE gets ou and walks rapidly away. INT. MAC’S CAR - CONTINUOUS On MAC as he drives off. ANGLE on her receding figure in the rear-view mirror. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - NIGHT Rain hammers the window. MAC’s at a computer, typing up a report. He looks up as a couple of men approach KATE FLETCHER’s office. He watches through the glass as she shakes hands and squeezes shoulders. MAC frowns. Doesn’t like the look of this. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - HER BEDROOM - NIGHT Alone in the half-darkness, she opens her underwear drawe and takes out the emergency bleeper. She wraps it in a sock, stands on her bed, lifts a corner panel in the ceiling and stores it in a nook above. INT. IRA CHIEF OF STAFF’S DAIRY BARN - SOUTH ARMAGH - NIG The IRA’s CHIEF is milking a cow as KEVIN MULGREW enters. The older man looks every inch the farmer he’s been all h life. Without missing a beat, he says;

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: Help me move her. MULGREW looks down at his new red trainers, but he’s got choice. They shift the cow and Mulgrew’s trainers end up covered in dung. The CHIEF OF STAFF looks pleased about this as he washes his hands in a giant metal basin. You m need a man like MULGREW, but you sure as hell don’t have like him.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is it? MULGREW. One of the McVeighs.  71. The CHIEF grunts in what sounds like derision. Shakes his head. MULGREW. (CONT’D) (insolent) Last time I looked, we hadn’t learned to love a tout.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: You'll start a war. Every eejit lining up against us’ll say we stitched up Gerry to please the Brits. He dries his hands on a towel.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which one? MULGREW. Maybe the sister. I’m working on it. The CHIEF throws the towel irritably onto the side.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: You'd better be right. Or it’1l be your neck on the block. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - NIG MAC steps in. FLETCHER is at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You did well today. A couple of paces closer.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You giving Barry Delavine a medal? FLETCHER smiles, shrugs. She’s not going to be drawn.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s with the love in?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You feeling left out, Mac? He doesn’t see the joke.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: He had another angle?  72.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No. But KATE FLETCHER is lying. For sure. She gets to her fee Wants to change the subject. FLETCHER (CONT’D) There’s a meeting tomorrow. They’11l use the boy’s funeral as cover. MAC doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you pick up anything more on Gerry? MAC shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: London’s worried. And so am I. But MAC is working over the earlier part of their conversation. What the hell is FLETCHER’S agenda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panoramic view of dawn breaking over this iconic graveyard at the heart of republican West Belfast -- the IRA's heartland. We sweep in to pick out two lonely figur winding through the headstones. COLLETTE and her MOTHER walk arm in arm. MA carries two bunches of flowers and a brand new LIVERPOOL scarf. They stop before a grave. The headstone reads; SEAN MICHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MA places one of the bunches in the vase and slips the Liverpool scarf around the headstone. The two women lean their heads together. Twenty years may have passed, but the pain has barely been dulled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of men in black leather jackets, white shirts, black ties and black shoes wait to carry BASEBALL CAP’s coffin. They’re surrounded by a crowd of mourners outside terraced house. GERRY MCVEIGH is among them. PADDY and COLLETTE stand either side of him. But we can pick out MA too. This is the community the IRA wants to believe it represents.  73. Cops dressed in riot gear pack the street. A helicopter hovers above. A shot from its MONITOR reveals the cops fanning out into dozens of surrounding alleys. It looks like a siege. In a sense, it is. BASEBALL CAP’s family stand by the doorway waiting for th procession to begin. They look tense. They wouldn’t have chosen an IRA ‘military’ funeral. As the coffin emerges, draped in an Irish flag, a police COMMANDER approaches GERRY, who is clearly the ranking IR man present. He raises his wooden baton.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: We agreed there’d be none of this. GERRY ignores him, nods for the pallbearers to continue. The officer raises his stick again. COMMANDER (CONT’D) No paramilitary displays. You’re not going to bury this man as a soldier, McVeigh. Not on my watch.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: There is no display.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: That’s a colour party.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s a few grieving men.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Split them up and have others carry it, or this is going nowhere. GERRY stares at the man. He oozes a visceral, tribal hatred, like those around him. But a confrontation would upset the family. Reluctantly, nods to the men to indicate he concedes. INT. CHURCH - A FEW MINUTES LATER. The coffin has reached the church, but there is no respit GERRY MCVEIGH sits close to the front of the mourners wit COLLETTE and PADDY still beside him.  74.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (from the pulpit) Whatever message we may wish to give to the massed ranks of the crown forces who besiege this church today, whatever hatred we may tell ourselves it is our right to harbour in our hearts, I must say this to the paramilitary leaders; why did you send this young man to his death? On GERRY as he tries to retain his composure.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After so many years of bitterness, what do you hope to achieve with this daily litany of death? Peace, as Yeats once told us, may come dropping slow, but come it must... On MA. The priest reflects her sentiments exactly. Back to GERRY, who really can’t stand to listen to much more of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The procession is shuffling along, surrounded by police officers in riot gear. It’s tense, but peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC is standing by a car the other side of the police fro the mourners. He’s in a baseball cap and tinted glasses, his collar turned up against the cold. He’s almost unrecognisable. He brings up his camera. THROUGH THE LENS as he fires off some shots; Gerry, Paddy, -- and then a series of IRA man who have filtered into the crowd, including the CHIEF. Snap. Snap... Boom! Chaos -- shouts -- people cowering -- screaming. What the fuck is happening? Boom!  75. SPIN AROUND. In the side street where MAC is standing -- barely fifty yards behind him -- a couple of guys in balaclavas are throwing home-made pipe bombs over the top of the cops and into the crowd. They’re shouting; up the UFF! Up the UFF! Loyalists. Protestant paramilitaries from the other side the wall. Men who claim to be fighting a covert war to protect the integrity of the British state against the IR which would like this territory to be reunited with the rest of Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GERRY, at the heart of the mourners.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Loyalists! Get down! He is still on his feet as everyone drops to the ground around him. PADDY and COLLETTE stay with him. They’re soldiers... EXT. SIDE STREET - CONTINUOUS. Cops dressed in riot gear turn away from the IRA mourners to face the loyalist thugs in the street behind them. The begin to charge towards the men, until one opens up with MACHINE GUN. Now everyone hits the deck, except... MAC. He is closest to the thugs, half-hidden behind a car ON HIM as he pulls out his Browning revolver. Shouldn't be doing this. Not his gig. He stands, aims, fires -- misses. One of the thugs has seen him, swings around... MAC doesn’t flinch. He steps into the road, takes aim again. Blam, blam, blam -- and the guy goes down. The other two thugs are still shouting. As one of them go to throw a pipe bomb, MAC CUTS HIM DOWN. One left. He hasn’t got a gun. He’s thrown his bombs. MAC closes in. The guy raises his hands. The cops have woken up and are advancing behind MAC, but some of the IRA men have slipped through the lines. They CHARGE towards the loyalist thug. Suddenly it’s a race to see who can get there first.  76. MAC wins, grabs him, turns his gun on the would-be lynch mob.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Get back! They keep coming. Slowly. With menace. The cops are tryin to push them away, but they want this guy bad. Voices. Yo lookin' after your Proddy friends? Bastards! A couple of the men lunge closer. MAC fires in the air. The men recoil for a moment, but it complete chaos. The crowd is SWELLING. The cops are tryin to BEAT THEM BACK. The cops REACH THE MAN, take him off MAC and try to get h out. There is pushing, shoving, shouting. MAC loses his hat... .-.as he finds himself opposite COLLETTE. She stares at him. And at that moment, she sees that MULGREW is watching her... INT. CONNOLLY HOUSE - A REPUBLICAN ‘COMMUNITY CENTRE’ - A HOUR LATER. A gathering of anyone who is anyone in the IRA. They’re still pumped up by the events outside.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? Did you see what just happened? PADDY and COLLETTE flank him. The CHIEF OF STAFF is on hi feet on a stage. He looks rattled.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: We're all angry, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Not angry enough!

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: They're trying to rattle us ‘cos they know we’re winning. If we move now, if we’re bold, we can isolate the Brits once and for all. ANGLE on an IRA hardliner called FOX. He’s another farmer head of the East Tyrone Brigade.  77.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: (from the front row) How's that, Seamus?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: We've got Dublin on board. Washington stands ready. But they need somethin’ from us. A moment’s silence. The audience is simmering with rage, but there are thoughtful faces too. The men around GERRY await his intervention. No doubt he’ the rebel leader.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (slowly, like this is hard to credit) You want a ceasefire now?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: We're not there yet, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: But that’s what you want?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: We have to test out--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What’s on the table?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: The Brits are talkin’ about a serious response to any gesture we--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What’s on the table is the square route of fuck all, so it is. What’s on the table is a document of surrender.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: Gerry, it’s a different way. We know that. But the cutting edge of the IRA’s sword is always going to be there, always ready. FOX and GERRY catch each other’s eye. There are murmurs of dissent. Someone mutters ‘Sell out’. We find COLLETTE as she slips away...  78. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - A FEW MINUTES LATER. Snow is falling and Christmas decorations are much in evidence as COLLETTE walks home. A voice behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You runnin’ away Collette? She spins around.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Christ! Kevin...you gave me a shock. ANGLE on his red trainers. They’re spotlessly clean again MULGREW. You know the guy?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Who? MULGREW. The Brit in the crowd. The one who shot our friends back there.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No. He waits, menacingly calm. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (finding strength in her terror) If you don’t mind me saying, Kevin, I think you’re getting a little paranoid. A beat. His eyes on her. She doesn’t flinch. MULGREW. Happy Christmas, Collette. I hope you get somethin’ nice for the wee fella. He walks away. INT. PHONE BOX - LONDON - NIGHT. MCILHATTON looks pissed off.  79.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (terse) You don’t need to know that.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: I've got everything ready. I've got everything he asked for, so-- She cuts the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL at the other end of the phone is locking up. She young and attractive. She can hear the phone ringing agai but doesn’t go back for it. With a start, she notices GER leaning against the wall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You gave me a shock. But it’s clearly a pleasant one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY and the GIRL fuck vigorously. Afterwards, in the dark;

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Wolf Tone called again. He’s always calling. He says everything’s ready. He keeps asking me; ‘when?’ GERRY gets up, still buck naked. He lights a cigarette, pulls back the edge of the curtain and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You never relax, Gerry, you know that? Not even when you're doing it to me. He looks at her like she’s from a different planet. And glances out of the window again...  80. EXT. MAC’S HOME IN ENGLAND - CHRISTMAS EVE A light dusting of snow on the drive of a suburban home. taxi pulls up and MAC gets out. He pays the driver and approaches the house. The lights are on in the living room window. His WIFE and daughter LUCY are wrapping presents by the tree. We can hear a Christmas carol; ‘As shepherds watched their flock by night...’ MAC manages a world-weary smile. Complicated as it may be it’s good to be home. He’s about to move to the front door when another man appears in the living room. He’s carrying a glass of champagne for MAC’s wife and she is SMILING AT HIM. CLOSE ON MAC. The price he’s paid... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - KITCHEN - DAY It’s Christmas day in the MCVEIGH HOUSEHOLD. COLLETTE is working through a mountain of washing up. Her MOTHER is drying. ANGLE on a newspaper folded on the side. EXCLUSIVE; IRA HARDLINERS REJECT PEACE BID. The rest of the family are watching T.V. next door and, a the Queen’s annual broadcast, comes on we hear;

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Switch the stupid cow off! The T.V is turned over. MA glances at the washing up stil to be done and smiles at COLLETTE

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: I blame myself. Your father never lifted a finger either.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Shame Christy’s got a bad back again... MA smiles. She turns around and steps into the doorway. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS. CHRISTY, GERRY and PADDY stare at the T.V.  81.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (without much conviction) I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: You're all right love. You relax there. Nobody appears to detect the note of irony. MA shakes her head. GERRY’s son LIAM has been driving a remote controlled car around the floor and at this moment he’s so excited he knocks over the table GERRY’s glass of beer has been standing on. GERRY leaps to his feet, soaked.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: For Fuck’s sake! What is wrong with you? LIAM is stunned. He was so happy for a moment there. He bursts out of the room and charges up the stairs. CHRISTY throws GERRY a furious look and follows. GERRY sets about clumsily cleaning up the mess, but MA pushes him aside. He storms out... EXT. COLLETTE’S BACK YARD - A MINUTE LATER. GERRY and MA stand together. It’s snowing. GERRY is smoki a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Don’t start, Ma. Not today. She watches him.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'd like you to let Collette go.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s her call. Always has been.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: It used to be. But she’s changed. Now she only stays in out of respect for you.  82.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You mean you’ve made her change. Isn’t that what you want for all of us? A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: (gently) Look what it’s doing to you, love.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We've been over this. You want to have the same conversation every Christmas till we’re dead?

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: Another year. Then another. Is that all we can hope for?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: If we give up now, it will all have been for nothing. Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: I only know I don’t want this. Not any more. GERRY closes his eyes. They’re all quitters. Every last o of them. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - A BEDROOM UPSTAIRS - A FEW MINUTES LATER. CHRISTY and LIAM on the bed, both with tear-stained eyes. GERRY sits down, puts an arm around his son.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. He pulls LIAM to him. CHRISTY cries again, but whether in happiness or sorrow it’s hard to tell. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - NIGHT MAC is sitting at a computer. We see him pull up a SEARCH function and type HENDERSON into the box. A raft of files. He clicks on IRA ASSASSINATION ATTEMPT. But it’s locked. The screen flashes up; Clearance level 9 Passcode;  83. He’s confused... EXT. FLETCHER’S HOUSE - NIGHT MAC rings the doorbell. It’s Christmas and FLETCHER’s husband answers. He’s wearing a stupid hat and looks at M with studied disinterest. He knows why he’s here. KATE emerges from the kitchen. She’s removing her apron.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Who is it, John? She sees.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mac. Are you okay? He nods. She shoves the apron into her husband's hand.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. The husband retreats in orderly silence. A small boy appears in the doorway of the kitchen. He’s about the sam age as Collette’s son.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Mummy, the mince pies are--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: In a minute, Louie. She shoos him back into the kitchen and closes the door. MAC can’t help noticing that he goes happily. She’s got it all, this one; husband, kids, job. Suddenly, he understands. What she said the other day was bang on the money. And the contrast with his own life is painful. INT. FLETCHER’S HOUSE - STUDY - CONTINUOUS. The pair sit in deep arm chairs in front of a roaring fir She roots around in her husband’s drinks cupboard and hol up a bottle of whisky triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Come on. It’s Christmas. He shakes his head. Like she ever drinks whisky.  84.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I’d known you were on your own, I'd have invited you to join us. No she wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shoot, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Why have you locked the Henderson file? KATE shrugs, like she doesn’t know what MAC is talking about.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe it was London.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: My Dad had an old saying; if it looks like a dog and barks like a dog, it’s a fucking dog.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (half smiling, but still as cool as you like) That’s a new one on me, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Barry Delavine works the same side of the street. So if you were pumping his hand, it must have been because he had another angle on Henderson. Another angle means another tout. KATE FLETCHER looks at him. She really doesn’t want to go here.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Collette McVeigh was your idea. So I’m asking myself; why?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Mac--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
