dialogues.text: I spend eight months reeling her in and you’re prepared to burn her on day one. Why?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Mac, please, I--  85.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you why; because you already have another agent in place. Someone close to her; bigger, better. Mulgrew and his friends started sniffing around, so you needed someone you could feed them if they get too close. She's grim-faced now.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’ve known worse results, Mac. He stares at her. He can’t quite believe he heard that.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s a good agent, but not a great one. Sometimes, we have to choose.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You cannot--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We can. And I do. That’s my job. There are no easy choices. This is a war. And we have to win it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) You think we can win anything if we're that cynical?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Do you think we can win if we’re not? Boy, two different styles.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: There are no winners here, Kate. There never have been. And there never will be.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: They chose this life, Mac. Let’s not forget that.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Even you can’t believe it’s that simple. They stare at each other. Both right, both wrong.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MCILHATTON watches from the crowd as the Prime Minister's Jaguar sweeps in. He glances up at Big Ben. It’s 3.10 exactly. But he’s getting pissed off with this. Planning for the operation that never comes... INT. COLLETTE’S BATHROOM - NIGHT She's brushing her teeth in the bathroom, with a towel around her middle. She goes to pull the curtains closed. MULGREW is standing in the alley, watching. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM - A MINUTE LATER. She climbs into bed in the darkness and stares at the ceiling. TERROR in her eyes again. She gets up, goes into the roof, takes out the emergency bleeper, puts it in her handbag and stuffs that under the bed. Lies down again. Wide awake. Like she’s going to be all night. She gets up, walks through to... INT. MARK’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS ...where she strokes her son’s head. She climbs onto the bed and curls her body around his. EXT. A PARK OFF THE FALLS ROAD - NIGHT. Three men with collars turned up against the rain; the Chief, Gerry, Mulgrew.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: It’s a fact. You’ve a tout. ANGLE on GERRY as the rain dribbles down his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kevin thinks your sister--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Leave my sister out of this. A beat.  87.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: (patiently) As I said, Kevin thinks--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Fuck what he thinks! GERRY looks at MULGREW with barely concealed contempt.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: That’s not possible any more, Gerry. I’ve spoken to the council. Nobody is against this. GERRY bites his lip, but smoulders with resentment.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kevin has a hunch that something may have happened to your sister in London. But given the stakes, I think we’ve got to go on more than hunches. Only you and your brother knew the full details of the Henderson operation, right? GERRY gives a barely perceptible nod.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then that’s where we should start. Say: guns into Hugo Street the day after tomorrow. You tell Paddy, but no one else. If the cops are waiting, it must be him. He’s in the clear, we move on to your sister... No answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got that, Gerry? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don’t co-operate, you’ll be stripped of your command and Kevin will get a free hand. A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you agree?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (through gritted teeth) You're wasting your fucking--  88.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: Do you agree? GERRY stares at MULGREW, the monster his war has created. With the utmost reluctance, he nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY MCVEIGH and the rebel IRA commander DECLAN FOX stan on the edge of a wood. FOX has a shotgun under his arm. He’s been killing rabbits. COLLETTE stands nearby, out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: It's sedition. You’ll get no support here.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s not support I want. I need to know there’1ll be no witch-hunt when it’s done. FOX glances at COLLETTE, starts walking. GERRY falls in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: You've got balls, McVeigh. I‘1l give you that. Thinks about the proposition.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘ll keep it to myself. You'll have that much chance, if you've the guts to go through with it. If you act quickly, if it’s as big as you say, maybe you'll carry people. Maybe. As to afterwards, I’m making no promises. EXT. COLLETTE’S BACK YARD - DAY MULGREW slips through the gate and reaches the BACK DOOR. He glances around him before PICKING THE LOCK... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS. He waits until he’s sure he’s alone. MULGREW’S P.O.V. as he looks at the photos on the mantel- piece. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS.  89. He checks the cereal cupboard, the drawers, the fridge... INT. GERRY’S CAR - SOUTH ARMAGH - DAY GERRY is driving. COLLETTE sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What time do you have to pick up Mark? COLLETTE looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: We're okay. COLETTE stares out of the window, asking herself why she’ here. She’s always been wary of her big brother, but never like this.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You ever wonder what Sean would look like now?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (trying to smile) Handsome.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You still think about him?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (where's this going?) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You’re the only one I can trust, Collette. No answer. What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quietly) I need you for something.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Gerry, I--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It has to be you.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What about Paddy? He shakes his head.  90. COLLETTE (CONT’D) But Gerry, I--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (tense now) Who's going to take any notice of me when they can look at--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Gerry, I--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Your picture is on the other pass. It has to be you. A beat, as the truth -- that she has no choice -- sinks i The price she paid for asking Sean to go and get those cigarettes. Still. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - IN THE HALLWAY - DAY COLLETTE wraps up against the cold. She glances at her watch. She’s late. Her MOTHER comes out of the kitchen. MA. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: Who's going to look after Mark? COLLETTE glances down the corridor. We can hear him playi in the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I won’t be long, Ma. MA. I've a doctor’s appointment.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Can’t you take him with you? I-- MA. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Just into town. MA. (steely) Then going ‘just into town’ can wait.  91.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (getting desperate) No it can’t Ma. Please...I have to go. She opens the door. Ma blocks her exit. MA. What are you going to do in town, Collette?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Ma, please... MA. No one has to go into town. No one ever has.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (close to tears now) Don’t do this. Not now. She pulls the door open and has to more or less force her way out. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - CONTINUOUS. She looks back. Her mother is standing in the doorway, watching. INT. MAC’S CAR - CENTRAL BELFAST - DAY. COLLETTE gets into the backseat, beside MAC.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You're late. The DRIVER accelerates away. COLLETTE puts her head in he hands.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I have to go. MAC glances over his shoulder to scope the road behind. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (agitated) I’ve made it here. You can see me. I need to get home.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: My mother is raging. I have to--  92.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Collette--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s watching me...Mulgrew. He waits. COLLETTE (CONT’D) He was in the alley last night. Standing there. Staring. Please...stop the car. They pull up at a set of lights and COLLETTE dashes out. MAC follows her. EXT. BELFAST STREET - CONTINUOUS. Ten swift paces and he catches up. They’ve reached a patc of abandoned industrial wasteland.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: This is unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You're the professional. I’m just a dead girl walking. He pulls her towards an alley, where they are out of sigh COLLETTE (CONT’D) I have to get home!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: We had a report in from East Tyrone that you and Gerry were seen at Fox’s house. He’s got his own man in London--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know about that! She shakes herself free, but he catches her. He forces he roughly into an abandoned factory; cavernous, spooky and damp.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You were with him at Fox’s place. Don’t tell me they were discussing the weather. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've a job to do, Collette.  No answer. 93.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: My job is to end up ina ditch...barefoot, hooded and dead. You know it and so do I!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (steely) We've been over this. It’s not going to end like--

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: How do you know? How can you possibly know?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What was Gerry doing with Fox?

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Collette, we’re under pressure here. You’ve got to give me more than this.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Or what?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Or this isn’t going to fucking work.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (sighs) I don’t know what they talked about. He said he needed my help for something.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He didn’t say.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: In London?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: He didn’t tell me anything.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: But he wants you to go with him?  94.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. He said he doesn’t trust anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What about Paddy? She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you said you would? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quieter) You have to go with him, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I can’t leave my son again.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: There’s no choice. You gave up the right to... She suddenly breaks free again, runs up a set of stairs a all the way along the first floor. He catches her by a broken window, which affords a panoramic view of the city

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (quietly -- she’s totally petrified now) I'm dead. That’s the choice I made.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. Stay close to Gerry and see this through and you're out. I give you my word. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: It won’t happen. It’1ll never end like that. (sighs, shakes her head) Where would I even go?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Anywhere you want.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: This is my home.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Collette, there’s a better life out there.  95. He takes hold of her arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Believe me. She stares at him. Seismic tension now. She wants to believe him. My God, this minute, she wants more than anything in the world... He still has a hold of her wrist. She drifts closer, her face only inches from his. She finds his hand... Touching. Linked fingers. Locked. Tight. They kiss. Suppressed passion explodes and they’re all ov each other. Against the wall. He lifts her coat, her dres Fumbling. Groping. Hushed, urgent, crazy... He’s almost in her. He staggers back. She stands, clothes dishevelled. Madness... He raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... INT. MAC’S CAR - MINUTES LATER. MAC gets in. Through the windscreen, we can see COLLETTE walking away up the road.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Sir, are you... The look on MAC’s face tells him to shut the hell up. He accelerates away past COLLETTE. She does not raise her head.  96. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - AN HOUR LATER. COLLETTE is in the hall. She takes off her coat, unwinds her scarf, closes her eyes and leans against the wall. She hears voices. The door to the yard must be open. GERR and PADDY sit on the steps with their backs to her. MA is at a garden table playing with MARK. COLLETTE approaches, then checks herself. They are having an argument.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t want Sandy to do it, I want you.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: What difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s a big shipment and we need to make sure it comes in okay.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (sighs) When?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, before dawn.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: The safe house in Hugo Street. You'll need to split it up quick. COLLETTE watches her mother playing with MARK for a momen then pulls back into the shadows. INT - TELEPHONE BOX NEAR COLLETTE’S HOME - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Box Man. She waits.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (business-like) How can I help?  97. She waits. What did she expect?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about... Nothing. COLLETTE (CONT’D) I understand. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What do you need, Shadow Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: There are some guns coming into Hugo Street. I overheard.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow before dawn. But you’ll be careful? I--

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll take care of it. You know what the guns are to be used for?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you have any more on your brother’s plans?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: No...not yet. I know what I have to do and...I’1l do it. He severs the connection. COLLETTE replaces the receiver slowly. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - SITUATION ROOM - NIGHT. MAC and FLETCHER pour over a city MAP.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: If we cut off the roads into Hugo Street, we'll have to cover ourselves with checkpoints all the way down the Falls. Another officer comes to the door to interrupt. It is one of the men MAC saw being congratulated by FLETCHER the other day. He’s in a hurry.  98.

dialogues.speaker: DELAVINE
dialogues.text: Ma’am... He checks himself.

dialogues.speaker: DELAVINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a report in. Some guns into Hugo Street tomorrow morning, before dawn. Looks like it could be a big shipment. FLETCHER looks shifty. These two sources sure are close t each other...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We're aware of it, Barry. Thanks. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - NIGHT. COLLETTE is reading MARK a story: The Jungle Book.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: ‘'Thou wilt not forget thou art a wolf? Men will not make thee forget?’ said Gray Brother anxiously. ‘Never,’ said Mowgli, ‘I will always remember that I love thee and all in our cave; but also I will always remember that I have been cast out of the pack...’’

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Does Mowgli prefer to be with the wolves or the humans?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, love. I think he feels his loyalties are divided. It’s very difficult for him.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: But where is he happiest? She closes the book.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You'll just have to wait and see. MARK wraps his arm around her waist and snuggles against her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two youths chewing gum, listening to music on the radio a they drive. The younger of the pair is behind the wheel.  99. DRIVER'S P.O.V. as they round a corner and spot a police checkpoint up ahead in the half-darkness. A COP waves his light baton in a circle to indicate they should stop.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: OLDER YOUTH
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: OLDER YOUTH
dialogues.text: Keep going, or they’1l shoot! The driver slows, winds down his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot struggling for focus. We see a man spinning around and moving away. All we can see is a dark coat and a pair of BRIGHT RED TRAINERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY McVEIGH watches. He sees the driver get out and ope the boot. The police officer pulls away a hidden floor to reveal the weapons. GERRY steps back from the window. He’s ashen faced as the implications sink in. His brother is a tout. EXT. PADDY MCVEIGH’S HOUSE - A FEW MINUTES LATER. The camera picks up MULGREW as he gets out of a car and strides towards PADDY’S house. He knocks hard. A second time. A third. Paddy’s face at the window. Frowns. He opens the door.  100.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: What do you want? MULGREW. You’1l need to come with us, Volunteer McVeigh.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me: I’ve won a free holiday. MULGREW pulls out his pistol and points it at PADDY’S hea MULGREW. McVeigh, you are under arrest on suspicion of being an informer for the crown forces. If you try anything stupid, I’1l spread your brains all over Belfast. He takes hold of PADDY, who is naked but for a pair of tracksuit bottoms and marches him to the van. NEW ANGLE: through a window, we catch GERRY sitting in a car further down the street, watching.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE MCVEIGH
dialogues.text: Awake. Staring at the ceiling, MARK asleep beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY in front of his baby brother SEAN’S HEADSTONE. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM - HALF AN HOUR LATER We hold the silence. There’s someone here. GERRY has slipped in like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Gerry-- He has a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (softly) We've got to go now Collette. She sits up.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get up. Say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Get dressed, Collette. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LANDING - CONTINUOUS. 101. GERRY'S P.O.V. as he emerges from the bedroom. His mother blocks the way. MA. What are you doing, Gerard?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (softly) Go back to bed, Mother. MA. Where are you taking her?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She’1ll only be gone a few days. MA. Leave her.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s not for you to decide. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM — CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE stands over MARK, who is still asleep. Tears in her eyes as she brushes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She joins her brother. MA blocks the way. GERRY pushes past her, but MA physically grabs a hold of her daughter. MA. Don’t. He’s dead to us. He has no feeling left.  102. COLLETTE is too dazed to respond.

dialogues.speaker: MA., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s using you.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Please, Ma. MA. I can see how he bullies you, Collette. It wasn’t your fault...

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: That’s not what it’s about Mam... Now they’re grappling with each other. Collette cups her mother’s cheeks. A desperate half-embrace and then she rips herself free. MA stands at the top of the stairs, tears in her eyes. She sits down on the steps and begins to sob uncontrollably. INT. COLLETTE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS. ON MARK as he sleeps. He rolls over, clutches a teddy bea to his mouth; the picture of innocence.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is Paddy coming with us? No answer. COLLETTE (CONT’D) What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What we have to. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEVIN MULGREW and a burly sidekick yank PADDY MCVEIGH fro a chair and push his head into a bath full of cold water. And out again. MULGREW. Shall we start over?  103.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mulgrew. MULGREW sighs, shakes his head. Why do they make it so ha on themselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE and GERRY walk through security. On the tannoy:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is the final call for Aer Lingus Flight 313 to Paris. COLLETTE looks highly agitated. She points towards the ‘toilet’ sign and separates herself from GERRY. She walks into the rest-room and then, after a brief wait, out agai checking that he is nowhere to be seen. She walks to a telephone box, takes out a couple of coins and dials. Waits. GERRY right beside her.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (annoyed, suspicious) What are you doing, Collette? She cuts the connection.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (thinking quickly) I...just wanted to see how he was.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No calls. We don’t know who’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PADDY’s head UNDERWATER ANGLE on MULGREW as he pulls him up again. MULGREW. Where shall we start?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mulgrew. Under he goes.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY and COLLETTE sit next to each other as the plane takes off. INT. FLETCHER’S OFFICE - MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - DAY MAC bursts in...

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: They’re on the move: Dublin, bound for Paris.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: She called in?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: An Irish cop spotted Gerry. He was spooling through CCTV footage of the security queue, looking for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE and GERRY appear nervous as they approach immigration control. ANGLE on the their false passports. They sail through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLETCHER and MAC run towards the open door of a waiting chinook helicopter. It immediately takes off and twists s wards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French detectives flood the security barrier. Too late... INT. MI5’S LONDON HQ - CONTROL ROOM - DAY MAC and FLETCHER striding in. People at desks, on the phone. A map of PARIS on the big central screen.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Have we got ‘em? A guy with his sleeves rolled up shakes his head. He star moving the mouse to bring up images on screen. Grainy CCT footage of the pair getting into a taxi.  Clicks to 105.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Leaving the airport... a different screen.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We found the driver. He took them to the Gare de Lyon. We picked them up...here... More CCTV footage.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gerry is standing right under the camera. He wanted us to clock him. A few minutes later they disappear. But we worked the angles and...bingo...Les Halles metro station. Pictures of the two of them leaving Les Halles.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They walked off in the direction of Ile de la Cite. The French have put hundreds of boots on the ground, but so far...

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You think Paris is the destination? The man shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE and GERRY have just finished dinner. COLLETTE is looking at a couple with young kids at the table next to her. Gerry glances at them.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You ever think about a different life, Gerry?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: All the time.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Will you do anything about it?  106.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: One day. But no one ever used to care about us. And now they do. She contemplates this. It’s undeniably true.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What’s going to happen tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Something to make everyone wake up.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Will we walk away from it?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’ve planned well, Collette. He glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s turn in. We’ve an early start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEVIN MULGREW swings a punch. PADDY absorbs it, rocks in the chair to which he is tied. He is naked, covered in sweat and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY is turning in, still more or less fully dressed. COLLETTE lies in the single bed next to him. GERRY takes out a revolver and puts it under his pillow. He switches out the light. INT. MI5’S HEADQUARTERS - CONTROL ROOM - NIGHT MAC is leaning on a desk, surrounded by officers working through the night. The Ops guy is pulling up potential targets on the big screen.  107.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER
dialogues.text: The British Embassy. We've discussed that. Moves on.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPS OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We think the residence is a better target. The Ambassador is a distant cousin of the Queen and the house itself is more--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (straightening) It’s not Paris. They all look at him, including FLETCHER.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gerry McVeigh wants something big enough to derail the process. That ain’t the British ambassador or any other target in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: He needs scale or scope. Scale; maybe a military barracks. He could drive to one of the Rhineland bases in a night. Scope; we should run a check on all the grade one targets and their movements over the next 24 hours; the Queen, Prime Minister, Charles. We know Gerry’s had his own man in London. Stands to reason this is why.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: But we've got every exit covered. If they move out of Paris, we’ll pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Depends how good he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE lies awake in the dark. GERRY appears to be asle in the bed next to her. Very quietly, COLLETTE slips from under the sheets, pulls coat over her shirt and moves towards the door.  108.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Collette?

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh...I can’t sleep. I just wanted some air.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Stay here. You never know who’s watching. She returns to her bed. No doubt she’s his prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY is standing by the window as COLLETTE awakes. She dresses. A beat. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is Paddy coming here?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is he meeting us somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Stop talking about Paddy.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (frowns ) Why?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: He’s with Kevin Mulgrew.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (confused) But--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We set him a test. Guns into Hugo Street.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He failed it.  109. This can’t be happening.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: You set him a test? No answer. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (horrified) But he’s our brother.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: He was our brother.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: He’s not my brother if he’s a tout. COLLETTE stands. She’s shaking. GERRY turns towards her. His face is contorted with RAGE.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything we've ever done; every bastard we've lost, every sod who's gone down for a spell in the Kesh...him. Our brother. He was touting when the peelers gunned down that kid last week. He was touting when they killed your Davey...He’s not our brother any more. Now her world is falling apart... INT. MI5 HEADQUARTERS - CHIEF’S OFFICE - DAWN Around the table with MI5 CHIEF ALAN BUCHANAN sit MAC, KA FLETCHER, the MI5 OPS OFFICER and a couple of other SECTI HEADS.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OFFICER
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No, she’s at Windsor all day. Prince Charles is having lunch with Thabo Mbeki at South Africa House.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Ask him to cancel.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We have. He won't.  110.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: What about the PM?

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OFFICER
dialogues.text: Only Prime Ministers questions. Otherwise Downing Street.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Who else?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: The Home Secretary is in Ealing. He won’t cancel either. The Deputy Prime Minister is giving a speech at the QE2...

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Any word from the French?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: No. You can see the tension in every face. The clock is ticki and they've got nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: We have an agent on the inside? They look at MAC.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Reliable?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Any chance she’s cut us off?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: (acid) Then how come, Mr Macintosh, we're sitting here in the dark?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Gerry McVeigh is a careful man. He'll be watching her. No phone calls. No contact. But she’1l find a way. BUCHANAN turns to FLETCHER.  111.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: What about our old friend in Belfast; Red Fox? The code name of the other agent. The first time MAC has heard it.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Nothing yet, sir. Barry Delavine is trying to make contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PADDY is still in the chair, half dead. MULGREW has a pai of pliers in his hand. He yanks PADDY’s legs apart and cu his testicles. MULGREW. We’re down to the wire here, Paddy my friend. I’m tired, you're tired. We all want to go home. So here’s how it is; we put your balls in this wrench and if we don’t like the answers we get, we twist. And we keep twisting until they come right off. PADDY is crying in despair, anger and shame.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: When Gerry-- MULGREW. Gerry! Please! Don’t insult my intelligence. Your brother knows you're here! He set the trap! Turns out our Gerry doesn’t like filthy, dirty little touts any more than the rest of us. So let's start again. How long have you been an agent for the British Secret Service?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mulgrew. MULGREW twists the wrench.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aaaaagh! Jesus! MULGREW. Who did you tell about the operation on Henderson? PADDY’S head sags.  He shakes 112.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Collette. MULGREW. No one else? his head. MULGREW. (CONT’D) Who did you tell about the guns coming into Hugo Street?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: No one. MULGREW furiously twists the pliers again.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aaaaagh!!!! MULGREW. Then it must be you who’s the tout, right Paddy? You say it yourself; only you knew about BOTH operations. Twists again.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Aaaagh!!!! Sweet Jesus!! I’m not a tout. I’m not a fucking tout! MULGREW lets go and sits back, frustrated, but genuinely perplexed. Crazy guy. A thought Ballsy. Ha ha. strikes him. MULGREW. Where did Gerry tell you about the guns?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: At home. MULGREW. Where exactly?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: On the back step. MULGREW. And there was no one else around, you say?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: No one.  113. Another beat. Still turning it over in his mind. MULGREW. Where was the boy? Collette’s wee nipper? PADDY shrugs in despair. MULGREW. (CONT’D) Was he in the house? Was he in the yard?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: In the yard. MULGREW. Who was looking after him?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Ma. MULGREW. Where was Collette?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Out. MULGREW. So your mother was in the yard?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Of course. MULGREW steps back, turns to his colleagues. MULGREW. Get him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY and COLLETTE emerge from the hotel. They amble down the side street as GERRY sizes up the cars. He picks one, breaks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE and GERRY with the wind in their hair. COLLETTE looks SHATTERED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man is waiting on the quay as the boat docks. He hands GERRY a brown envelope without a word.  114. GERRY tips it up. We see two HOUSE OF COMMONS staff passe one for each of them.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Michael has the other boat?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: He'll be waiting. GERRY nods. He squires COLLETTE firmly to the car, like a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MI5’S HEADQUARTERS - CONTROL ROOM - DAY MAC stares out of the window. FLETCHER stands beside him. A telephone is on the desk between them. It does not ring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MULGREW and his gang march PADDY to a ditch. He is still naked but for the bag over his head. They force him to kneel. MULGREW. Last chance, my friend. PADDY shakes his head. MULGREW. (CONT’D) Admit youse’re a tout and I’1l spare your worthless life. YOUTH. Boss... MULGREW. Shut up! One more chance, McVeigh, then I’m out of patience.  115.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mulgrew. I'll see you in hell. They wait. MULGREW puts a pistol to Paddy's head.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pull the trigger, you coward. MULGREW pushes the pistol down. CLOSE again on the faces his crew. They’re shitting themselves. TIGHT on MULGREW. He kicks PADDY into the ditch. MULGREW. Get him out of here. He’s not who we're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY takes COLLETTE to a station cafe and parks her at a table. He moves to the phone box in the corner. But he’s still watching her... INT. MULGREW’S VAN - SOUTH ARMAGH - DAY A mobile phone attached to a large unit on the dash rings as PADDY is being loaded into the rear. MULGREW jumps int the passenger seat and answers. MULGREW. Lightning delivery services.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What happened to the package? MULGREW. It hasn't reached its final destination. We’re looking at something else. The mother of all packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY puts down the telephone slowly. He is white with shock. He goes to the table and takes COLLETTE’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What is it?  116.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY marches COLLETTE across the bridge. He puts a HOUSE OF COMMONS PASS around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What’s happened, Gerry? She shakes herself free. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Who did you call? It was about Paddy...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Paddy isn’t our tout.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Someone else.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: (terrified) But--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Someone who's always been with us. Right from the start...from the day we were born... He grips her arm again. She grapples with his meaning. It cannot be. He cannot mean... INT. CAFE OVERLOOKING THE HOUSE OF COMMONS - DAY. GERRY, COLLETTE AND MCILLHATTON sit at a corner table, wi a view over Westminster and the Houses of Parliament. Almost alone, they are staring out of the window and MCILLHATTON, in particular, does not like what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: It’s crawling with peelers!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Give me the bag.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: We don’t stand a chance! GERRY rips the bag from his hand and leans forward.  117.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (menacing) Listen to me. They’1l have tightened security all over this and every other town. But they weren’t on our tail and they don’t know we’re here. So we stick to the plan.

dialogues.speaker: MCILLHATTON
dialogues.text: You’1l never make it!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We're going now. Just make sure the boat is there... GERRY takes the bag, puts it over his shoulder and hauls COLLETTE to her feet. EXT. WESTMINSTER TUBE STATION - DAY. Down the steps. GERRY puts his arm around COLLETTE, like they are lovers.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smile. A small group of cops is being briefed by a COMMANDER. Th security guard glances at them for a moment, examines the passes. He’s distracted by a call from his supervisor behind him. GERRY and COLLETTE walk on. They wait to be stopped, but there is no shout... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - CONTINUOUS. Along the underpass. GERRY turns left, through to a terrace overlooking the THAMES. He glances about. An official approaches.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: This is for members only sir. GERRY smiles. They double back. They reach a stairwell and climb. They pass a journalist running down.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Morning.  118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRIME MINISTER leaves Number Ten and gets into his JAGUAR. The car accelerates towards giant iron gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY turns off the stairwell and leads COLLETTE down an empty corridor. He pushes her into the ladies toilet and closes the door. He unzips the bag, presses a pistol and a balaclava into her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Lock the door. I’1l knock three times. He’s gone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRIME MINISTER'S JAGUAR sweeps into the Palace of Westminster. He gets out and disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE is still DAZED. A beat as she turns it all over in her mind... INT. MI5’S LONDON HQ - CONTROL ROOM - DAY BUCHANAN at the centre of an informal huddle. He’s lookin at MAC.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Still nothing? MAC shakes his head. BUCHANAN (CONT’D) You hold to your judgement?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: She’11l come through. BUCHANAN turns to FLETCHER.

dialogues.speaker: BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: What about Red Fox?  119.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Barry’s made contact sir, but she can’t fill in the missing pieces. She’s done all she can. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME IN BELFAST - DAY MA is feeding the kids. A doorbell goes. She answers. MULGREW. Hello, Mrs McVeigh. MA. Hello, Kevin. MULGREW. I guess you’ve been expecting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE opens the door of the toilet and steps out into corridor. She moves along silently. She's looking for a telephone or an empty office, but there’s nothing. She reaches an alcove by the stairs. Waits a moment. CLOSE on her. A moment of DECISION. She takes out the emergency BLEEPER. She PUSHES the button. A light starts flashing. She hides it behind a book shelf and turns into the stairwell... INT. MI5’S LONDON HQ - CONTROL ROOM - A SPLIT SECOND LATE Still in the huddle.

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPERATIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: We've got something! They turn to face the screen. A map of central London. A dot. Zooming in...

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: She’s set off her emergency bleeper. Going closer...the HOUSE OF COMMONS

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ...  120. He bursts out of the door...

dialogues.speaker: MI5 OPERATIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: (shouted after him) The Press Gallery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Speaker is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Questions to the Prime Minister! INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY MULGREW is sitting opposite MA.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) There won’t be any need for that, Kevin. I’1l tell you what you need to know. My code name is Red Fox. She glances down the corridor at the kids, still eating their lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC careering down the stairs... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY MA. (sighs) Long ago. They said they had enough evidence to put Paddy in prison for the rest of his life. I'd lost one son. I didn’t want to lose another. Wouldn’t you have done the same, Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC pounds the pavement, past startled tourists. Sirens WAILING. Cops STREAMING in from all directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY returns to the ladies toilet to find COLLETTE is no there.  121. He shakes his head in FURY. The final BETRAYAL. He pulls a balaclava over his head and walks along the corridor to the stairs, past a pair of startled journalists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC charges through the gate holding up his pass. He tear around the yard inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLETTE is walking away from BIG BEN, but there are poli cars and sirens everywhere now, so she stops and turns ba to face the COMMONS. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - DAY. MAC bursts into the bottom of the stairwell, a Browning pistol in his hand... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - CHAMBER - CONTINUOUS.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: The Leader of the Opposition... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - STAIRWELL - CONTINUOUS. MAC runs into a large group of officials walking down the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Move! He smashes through... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - CHAMBER - CONTINUOUS.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
dialogues.text: (getting to his feet) Could the Prime Minister please tell the house whether he advised the United States Government to grant Mr Gerry Adams a visa to visit Boston, New York and Washington?  122. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - PRESS GALLERY - CONTINUOUS. GERRY closing on the chamber. A startled official steps forward to stop him, but GERRY smashes him to the ground with the butt of his revolver. He opens the door. We hear the roar of the chamber... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - CHAMBER - CONTINUOUS.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: The right honourable gentlemen knows, as do all members of this house, that the government is committed to the defeat of terrorism in all its forms.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: Hacks, officials...all stunned, paralysed...GERRY is slow walking towards the front.... INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - PRESS GALLERY - CONTINUOUS. MAC jumps a desk, slides across a wide central table stre with press releases and bursts through the door...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: .»+.as GERRY raises his gun arm. Screams. Shouts. He’s going to shoot the Prime Minister. The PM looks up... As MAC tears in...

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Gerry! GERRY hesitates a split second -- just long enough for MA to hit him running at full pelt. They career into the balustrade -- tip over... Smack into the floor below. Pandemonium. MAC wrestling with GERRY. More shouts. Screams. People sprinting from the chamber.  123. The Prime Minister’s bodyguards charging in -- pulling their man out -- looking for a shot at GERRY. Too many MP in the way... GERRY has lost his revolver. But he’s on his feet...running... Out into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...-where he charges a startled cop. Head butts him. Grab his revolver. Turns back to face MAC. A shot. MAC hits the deck. Another cop on the other side of the lobby reacts. Blam! Blam! But Gerry is running again. Out into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..+.-where members of the public are scattering in panic. GERRY fires twice in the air. Chaos again. On MAC as he fights against the tide of people fleeing. He still has his revolver, but there’s no way he’s going get a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY pounding down a massively long, half-deserted corridor. A couple of startled clerks. Some businessmen waiting for a meeting. GERRY turns. Kneels. As MAC comes around the corner, blam, blam! This time he’s got him. ON MAC as he goes down. Hit in the arm. Sodding terrible pain. GERRY ducks through a door.  124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spiral staircase. Pounding up it. Breathing ragged. MAC crashes through the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: There’s no way out, Gerry. GERRY fires another shot, but misses. He bursts out onto the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...-where he sprints towards Big Ben -- in any other mome the most epic, stellar view of London.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: A swooping circular shot of the pair of them running as M emerges onto the roof and gives chase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERRY reaches the side that overlooks the river. Nowhere else to go. He looks down at the water -- there is indeed boat waiting on the far side -- then turns to face his pursuer. Both men have gun arms raised. Like a duel.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: It’s over Gerry. The IRA man stares back. It’ll never be over. Click! He’s tried to fire, but there’s nothing left in the chamber. The thud of a helicopter above, of sirens in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s over. GERRY turns, runs, jumps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-Smacks into the wall of the terrace below and slumps into the river. His body slips under the water, then surfaces again, befo the tide slowly sweeps it away. The man in the boat opposite roars off. EXT. HOUSE OF COMMONS - ROOF. ON MAC as he looks down. The end he deserved. But still... The death of a man. Of an idea. MAC understood his journey, his choices. But sooner or later we have to take responsibility for the decisions we make.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - DAY ON MA, who now faces up to the decision she made. MULGREW is putting on his coat. MARK runs down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Who is it, Grandma? MA. It's a friend, Marky. Just a friend. MULGREW. I think we should go now, Mrs McVeigh. A look of terrible sadness in MA’s eyes. She has awaited this moment for so long, has known it was inevitable, but now that it is upon her the agony is unbearable. The phone rings. MULGREW goes to answer...  126. INT. TELEPHONE BOX - WATERLOO - CONTINUOUS. It is COLLETTE who is calling.

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: COLLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s Collette. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about youse, pet?

dialogues.speaker: COLLLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s me you want.

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: COLLLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m the tout. I’1l give myself up. I‘ll exchange myself for her.

dialogues.speaker: MULGREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right, Pet. A deal’s a deal. CLOSE on COLLETTE. The sound of her breathing... FADE TO BLACK. STILL IN BLACKNESS: THE SOUND OF A SPADE ON WET TURF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC and KATE FLETCHER watch two uniformed police constabl digging. Gradually, they reveal something wrapped in a plastic sheet. They struggle to pull it free. It comes out of the wet earth with a dull pop. The cops stare at FLETCHER and MAC. FLETCHER nods grimly. They cut away at the tarpaulin and peel it back to reveal... MA's face. White. Dead.  127. They stare. MAC looks at FLETCHER.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You worked out who won yet? MAC turns away in disgust, walks up a slippery path to th flat parking area of a gravel pit. As he emerges, COLLETT climbs out of the car in which she has been waiting. She comes towards him. She looks SHATTERED.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: Is it her? He doesn’t answer. Doesn’t have to. COLLETTE tries to get past, but he catches her. COLLETTE (CONT’D) Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Stay here, Collette.

dialogues.speaker: COLLETTE
dialogues.text: I said I'd give myself up. I said I’d-- She's fighting him, trying to break free.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: It doesn’t work like that. She's breaking down now. Inconsolable. Her mother. Inadvertently but inevitably, she’s killed her. Two touts, too close. One was bound to die. MAC scoops her up like a child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets into the back seat with her, next to MARK, who is waiting there, bewildered. MAC nods at the driver. They pull out of the quarry, turn down the hill. MAC draws COLLETTE and MARK close to him. They do not resist his protective embrace. His family now...  128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on FLETCHER, who stands at the top of the quarry. She watches them go. These people - they made their decisions. Not her problem. In war, it only matters that the good guys win. FADE TO BLACK.
